comments.commentBody: There are enough examples of Islamic radicals who take to militant Islam despite prosperity. Feisal Shehzad and many other gainfully occupied youth of IT companies are live examples. ISIS twitter handle was managed by a Muslim youth employed in a good steady job in India. Pl scan news for those names. Saudi Arabia has prosperity but practices Wahabism; the most radical form of Islam. Mainstream Islamic thought regards the successful life of the Prophet and the spread of Islam through history by whatever means as a historical vindication of its truth.  While such incidents are new to Western Europe, much of Asia has lived for the past millennium through  such violence in the course of spread of various forms of Islam. That is where the battle of ideas has to be waged. Dilution of faith is a necessary ingredient in the armoury of the civilized world. Unless we clearly identify the problem, we will never solve it. Economic development is quite definitely not the answer.

I suggest you read the Jewish Press (it does not have to be Israeli) from Europe or US re the precarious situation of the Jews in France.
Basically the community is doomed. The daily anti-Semitic attacks by Muslims is not reported by the regular press and not really dealt with, unless it is something like the attack on the kosher market.
Jews in France are packing their suitcases, whether for Israel, Canada or the US (with the latter being of course the most difficult to get into).
During the summer, French Jews, moving to Ashdod in Israel, which was being bombed non-stop, were asked why they chose to move to Israel then and to Ashdod of all places. Their answer: it was safer in Ashdod under attack than in France.
France will not provide security to its Jewish citizens and I am not sure that they can.

You comment is unfair to the hundreds of thousands of loyal Moslem Frenchmen and women who work and live alongside their co-citizens of all faiths in peace and harmony. The reasons for low self-esteem are manyfold and may have nothing to do with one's faith, color or creed but are used all too often as an excuse for her inexcusable. Of course things after not perfect, anywhere, but where the majority make the best of it there will always be those who harbor a grudge against society or specific sections of it and who need to be identified and appropriately helped so that they do not become a threat to themselves and others. There have been too may failures in intelligence follow-up in this case and in many others, including the Twin Towers, and this is the most inexcusable factor in the loss of so many human lives.

These are interesting speculations and I hope that France will rise to the challenge of ensuring diversity and inclusion while quelling Islamic extremism. I am particularly concerned about the fate of France's Jewish community, which has become increasingly victimized in this unstable environment.

To my mind, part of the solution is a growing economy that emphasizes employment opportunities for young people who might, in the absence of meaningful work, embrace radicalism. It is worth remembering that the brothers who conceived of and guided the Charlie Hebdo attack came to radical Islam only after secular life proved disappointing with respect to careers and futures. To my mind, the failure of many economies to provide sufficient employment is a harbinger of isolation, alienation and radicalism.

I am very glad to see the solidarity of the French people in the wake of this attack, and appreciate the French commitment to free speech and an open society. Je suis Charlie.

As a KIPP teacher, I can tell you your impression of KIPP is way off. KIPP is a lottery-based charter school; there's no selectivity. Students sign a commitment to excellence before coming, as do parents, but believe me, a good chunk of students and parents seem to forget what they signed within minutes. Some of the kids have involved and committed parents, but many don't (I have a student who is homeless because his father refuses to allow us to recommend him for CPS). Also, while grit is something we try to emphasize at KIPP, we, too, are much more invested in trying to achieve 2+ years of growth (particularly in math and reading, where our kids are every bit as low as yours) each year.

Thank you, Joel Parks! These were precisely my reactions to this piece and, even more, to a report about KIPP's character education on PBS's NewsHour this week. A focus on "grit," perseverance, and other abstract individual qualities should NEVER distract us from addressing the systemic problems that place such a high percentage of America's children in poverty. Mantras and pedagogical gimmicks cannot make up for the structural inequities in American education today.
But without "grit" they will succeed neither in school nor in life

Here are a couple of thoughts from a Los Angeles public school teacher of 7th-grade Social Studies.

First, to even implicitly compare KIPP schools, which are highly selective, demand and get great commitment from students and parents, to public schools, particularly those in neighborhoods of poverty, is specious. The KIPP kids are already miles ahead of the kids I teach, simply because of parental commitment and involvement.

Second, any discussion of "grit" takes us away from the biggest single driver of our so-called "achievement gap", which is poverty. Students who live in poverty have higher stress levels, get poorer nutrition, and tend to get ill more often than students who are not grindingly poor.

Teaching "grit" is fine, but many of my students come to me in the 7th-grade functioning at a 3rd-grade level or below. They need more than grit.

I agree. I believe that the terrorist attacks have less to do with France per se and more to due with this destructive faction of Muslims who are intent on destrying the world order. USA, Australia, France, etc. this loose group of radical violent find local opportunities for what they see as a global threat.
Yes, and how will that go over in kindergarten?

Schools should teach Aristotle, pure and simple. aristotle's ideas of character building, developing good habits, substituting good habits for bad habits, and practicing moderation are timeless. Teaching those ideas, even if they were merely taught about and not promoted, would improve the values of our society, would improve the national character, and would increase the happiness and virtue of individuals. Of course, I would prefer education that promotes Aristotle ideas.

I hope schools will stop promoting the Modernist ideas of the so-called 'Enlightment,". Where attemps to apply theories that worked quite well in the natural sciences have been a disaster in the social sciences. See communism, nazisn, racism, eugenics, and many other isms, and like libertarianism.

Teaching John Rawls and the theory of Social Justice, which is quite different from socialism and which supports a balance of economic opportunity with economic incentives, and allows individuals to balance priorities and values with economic growth, instead of considering only the almighty dollar as the exclusive value, would improve us and increase our happiness.
Since he is also a heavy smoker he has two strikes against him.
Spray on tan is probably safe....
I sure hope John Boehner reads this for his own sake...

You wrote...

"I respect the right of Charlie Hebdo to express what they want while simultaneously having no respect for most of the distasteful content they produced. If only more people could see that these two views are not mutually exclusive we would be in a better place. Unfortunately, we are not there yet."

Nonsense. Of course we're there in the west. We have satire, criticism, counter-satire, counter-criticism, peaceful demonstrations, Op-Eds, Facebook debates, and debates in the Comments section of the New York Times. Where we're not there yet is in the vast majority of the Muslim ummah, where people cannot express what they want, love who they want, change religions if they want, blaspheme if they want, read the books they want, and see the kind of content about which they can feel peaceful discontent. I woud include Gaza and the West Bank in that ummah.

In fact, here's the ironic thing: The place in the Middle East where Muslims have the greatest amount of freedom of speech and expression (including the right to love someone of the same sex without official comdemnation) is israel.

This comment echoes the 'Go Slow' nonsense that Southerners used as an excuse to vote against civil rights legislation. 'Don't upset the community for fear of backlash' is just an excuse to maintain the status quo. 'It's against my religion' is a great all-purpose excuse to avoid almost any civic responsibility, from paying taxes to integrated public restrooms.
Conservatives need to grow up and participate in modern society. Twenty-first century problems cannot be solved with nineteenth-century attitudes. What passed for 'social norms' then looks like bigotry today. Stand up and call it bigotry, don't institutionalize it by electing politicians and judges who are bigots, too. And certainly, don't defend it with specious rhetoric and obfuscation.
I agree with you. Other candidate profiles follow a theme of "______'s past moves raise questions of inconsistency" or "Shifting policies of _______ concern electorate".

Sidney Harris once wrote that 'all religions are true in what they affirm, and false in what they deny'. For decades, I quoted that phrase, and believed it.
Until now.
Now, we have a division in the public/media fueled consciousness between 'good' persons of faith, and 'religious extremists'. Religion is faith and nothing but faith. There is no truth, no proof, no logic to any religion. Just belief.
Some people believe that they can influence the outcome of a football game by the actions they take as they watch it on television. That's as genuine a faith that there is/are a/several gods, supernatural beings.
Whether one prays for the sun to rise in the east tomorrow, it will. Whether one prays for rain or dry weather, rain will come when the conditions are right. Prayer is not a prerequisite.
Frank, we both support the right of people to believe anything - but not to impose those beliefs on anyone else.

I agree that children perceive, learn and interact differently based on innate traits, such as degrees of introversion and extroversion. Teaching methods should be flexible so as to reach different children in the ways best suited to them.

At the same time, schools are a wonderful place to build character and teach coping skills. Both grit and flexibility can be taught to good effect. I see these characteristics as mutually reinforcing, by the way. Young people should learn to persist in achieving their goals, while realizing that they may need to stop, reassess and revise their methods to maximize their chances of success.

Grit and flexibility are both important life skills, as are resilience and an underlying sense of self worth.

It is so myopic to consider only Israel's reaction to an Iranian bomb. Neither the editorial, nor any of these select views, consider the repercussions of a nuclear arms race in the Middle East were Iran to develop the bomb. Iran has threatened not just Israel and it seeks hegemony over the region. The best path to stopping the bomb is with strong sanctions. The Iranians have much more to lose in this poker than the U.S.  And, Congress has a strong hand to play in this game.

Likewise, when the "Supreme Leader" abandons his expectation that Israel capitulate its national security in the face of Iranian threats, there will be a change in the Israeli perspective. Iran's negotiating in good faith, reaching an agreement and making peace with Israel, would constitute a substantial step towards making peace with the United States.

Article 51 of the United Nations Charter recognizes in each nation-state member, including Israel, an "inherent right to individual, or collective self-defense." Iran's path to peace must necessarily include making peace with all of its Middle East neighbors!

Unhappily there's another factor to be considered in all of this.  If Mr. Netanyahu continues to signal that nothing short of complete capitulation on the part of Iran vis a vis its nuclear program will be considered satisfactory our red-blooded, patriotic American congressmen will fall all over themselves to do his (and AIPAC's) bidding.  And that includes most of the Demcrats.  Making peace with Iran carries less importance for them than incurring the wrath of Bibi.

Charlie Hebdo has done many mockings of Jews and Moses. The apology you mentioned was because it was directed towards a specific individual.
On the other hand, The New York Times has refused to publish any cartoons of Mohammad or mocking Islam but have published the Iranian Holocaust cartoons and many cartoons insulting the Christian faith. Neither Jews nor Christians have gotten violent over this open lack of respect. Even if Charlie Hebdo did have a double standard that is their right too. I constantly see in the leftist media and academia an insensitivity, sometimes a downright hatred, openly flaunted towards Jews that would never be allowed towards blacks or Muslims.

WHo draws the line?

You?

Me?

Some Iman who is advocating jihad?

THat is why there is no LEGAL line.

"satire might be better served by an honest reckoning of whose voices we hear and don't hear, of who we mock and who we don't, and why."
I agree. We seem no longer capable of saying something is wrong because it's immoral, unethical or crosses a line in it's insulting behavior. As the author mentions, Charlie Hebdo dismissed an author when he wrote what some perceived to be an anti-Semite joke. Why did that cross a line and insulting another's religion did not?

Is it so important to deeply offend the disabled and terminally ill as South Park does, so that someone gets to laugh at a sick joke? Sure that's "freedom of expression" but why do we have to give up any notion of ethical behavior?

Your article, like the others in this debate series, was very insightful.  However, I would just like to mention that Family Guy's writers have lampooned the events of 9/11 and the deaths of American soldiers in Iraq and Afghanistan.  The episodes "Back to the Pilot" and "Thanksgiving" in Season 10 are perhaps the clearest examples.

For a young person (say roughly 15-25), if their family is very wealthy, the truth is that they do not "have to work" -- there is ample money for things like cars, insurance, vacations, and of course, college.

No need to hit the books so you get good grades, so you can have a scholarship -- because Mumsy and Pops have endowed a chair at Harvard. No need to earn the pittance needed for car insurance. No need to save up money for a car, because you got a BMW on your 16th birthday.

Such kids can't take summer jobs or Xmas break jobs, because the family has scheduled numerous long vacations in distant places. Sticking with an after-school job would be impossible if you have to go skiing on winter break, or to Europe on summer vacation.

Children of the wealthy are often given large sums of money (or gift cards) on every imaginable occasion (birthdays, Xmas), so they have plenty of pocket money. This makes the purchase of drugs or alcohol very easy.

What if the large number of depression diagnoses of "rich" teenagers include a significant number of false positives? What if psychologists making such diagnoses are biased by the prospect of years of lucrative income?
There is no objective method to prove/disprove depression, and teenagers who feel sad, behave be unruly, or daydream through mandatory classes aren't necessarily depressed. Poorer kids are more likely punished for such behaviors, while affluent kids get dragged to the therapist or psychiatrist, and promptly promote to patient -- and, parents and teachers live happy thereafter, resting assured that "it's not their fault".

As a psychologist in Manhattan I have treated many of these young adults. What I have found is that, because of their wealth, few need to seek full time employment or can "dabble". As a result, they are less motivated to seek and retain full time employment and are much more "directionless." Even if their parents expect that they work, it may somehow not happen because they don't "have to." At times, parents often expect these kids to somehow be available to them in one way or another that precludes career development.

Being employed means fuller participation in society and, at both end of the economic spectrum, there can be a high level of unemployemt (although for very different reasons).

There is also a culture of early drug use, as noted or more "designer" drugs, taken for "fun." The drug use also fills an emptiness, and then becomes a goal on its own.
That doesn't always work.  Some kids are bullied mercilessly by their unsupervised peers.  That said, you're right that independent play can be wonderful when bullying is not present.

My brother had that experience. He enrolled his kids in third grade in a Catholic school in a poor section of town. They did fine in university and in their careers. They went and came home by pubic transportation, occasionally getting a ride.

I had a friend, who like you -- through a combination of luck and hard work (remodeling) -- managed to get a small home in a very posh exurb. She was thrilled with the little cottage she had renovated and of course, she wanted the highly rated local school system.

But once her son was enrolled, she realized the problems there. The kids were snobbish and highly competitive. There were cliques and they deliberately excluded kids who could not participate in expensive activities like skiing or horseback riding. There was a HUGE culture in the schools of "having to have" the latest electronics and brand name clothing.

She ended up taking her son out of the public school, and putting him into a modest parochial school a couple of suburbs over.

Often when seeking a home, people are blinded by status and "the right zip code", or the potential for housing price appreciation -- and don't look closely at the culture.

After growing up in a blue-collar neighborhood, through hard work and the luck of the housing bubble, I eventually found myself raising a child in a highly affluent suburb.  Within a few months, my husband and I realized we had made a terrible mistake.  Lovely as it appeared, the stress was off the charts.   So much social competition and judgment and anxiety among the parents led to many a mean child.  I think your second to last paragraph is spot-on in terms of considering where to live when you raise your family.  I had no idea how much where you lived affected your life until. for the first time, I hated the place I lived.
Dave, Personality may be innate, but new coping skills can be taught to good effect.  And as research on neurplasticity suggests, people can change.

My parents were in business almost thirty years, and I learned early, if you take the public's money, you take the public, unless they are rude or excessively demanding, because you are in business to make a profit, not be a prophet enforcing the virtues of your own particularistic beliefs.
To take this to its extreme would demand that each business have its own form of 'Use Agreement' in which you agree not to be apart of any group I don't like or extol any view, philosophy, life style, sexual position, and on that I don't approve of. They would be long and cumbersome, filled with the same legal jargon we regularly check-off without bothering to read on-line, and ultimately have the same effect on the mind of everyone, except they would give comfort to those people that need them to maintain a life living for their resentments.

Milton Friedman was important as PK acknowledges but he was not as adherents claimed (including a PBS program) the greatest economist of the 20th Century - or a friend of Austrians.

The Economist in 2011 http://econ.st/1xb4NeH

"Milton Friedman was one of the 20th century's great economists as well as one of its most formidable debaters. This made him a powerful check on the influence of anarcho-capitalist Austrians, obviously much to the chagrin of Rothbard. "As in many other spheres," Rothbard wrote, "[Friedman] has functioned not as an opponent of statism and advocate of the free market, but as a technician advising the State on how to be more efficient in going about its evil work." Rothbard's fulminations notwithstanding, Mr Friedman died a beloved figure of the free-market right. Yet it does seem that his influence on the subject of his greatest technical competence, monetary theory, immediately and significantly waned after his death. This suggests to me that Friedman's monetary views were more tolerated than embraced by the free-market rank and file, and that his departure from the scene gave the longstanding suspicion that central banking is an essentially illegitimate criminal enterprise freer rein. When a significant portion of a political movement's activists believe that the whole point of central banking is "systematic robbery", and that inflation is the means by which this robbery takes place, widespread, reflexive opposition to inflation is not surprising."
I love that, "Pretend Jobs."
As another Floridian, I can only say "RIGHT ON!"

It's time for the NYT to stop serving us the daily swill about Jeb Bush.  I lived in Florida while this very thin-skinned guy was in office.  I witnessed the purge of the voter rolls that was in place to purge Democrats and black voters.  I saw the manipulation of the vote re-count.  I saw the things the GOP did to suppress the black vote -- namely -- I saw actual roadblocks to keep people away from polling places and the "scare" leaflets that were plastered in black and Hispanic-dominant areas to keep people away from polling places for fear of arrest.  I saw a governor who was so petty he barred certain reporters from covering his pressers because they wouldn't write puff pieces about him.  I saw the governor direct the FL public pension plan money into Kenny "Boy" Lay's fraud company ENRON as it was augering into the ground and taking careers, pensions, etc with it.  FL lost millions of dollars.  I saw a governor who pulled tax dollars out of public schools to finance charters, vouchers, and cyber schools that just ended up wasting millions of dollars that should have been in the public school system.  He's was a terrible governor and he's an unrepentant rightwinger who jumped into the Terri Schiavo situation -- a place where he didn't belong just as he doesn't belong in the White House.  Once an entitled Bush, always an entitled Bush.  And, oh yeah, he's never had an actual job -- just board seats and other pretend jobs all due to his family connections.

In the mid-1950s, my dear grandmother was still profoundly affected by memories of the death of her first baby, Cornelia, within a day of her birth in 1900. She was as matter-of-fact as possible when telling me, but her lingering sorrow was obvious. I'll always be grateful that she shared those personal feelings with me in a kindly and frank way. It made a special bond between us and helped me when I had to face the death of my own firstborns (twins). Death is part of life, and there should be no shame or guilt about continuing to have strong feelings for many years (obviously if they become crippling it's a different matter).
I have children but I live for my spouse.  Our children are a reflection of our love, and as our eldest enters adulthood, the greatest gift is to set them free.

Amazing.  Or maybe not.  Politicians are like this.  They believe whatever they think most likely to get them elected.  There is an old saying that when a man and a woman get married the man expects the woman to stay the same and the woman expects the man to change.  What actually happens is that the man stays the same and the woman changes.  With politicians, no matter what they claim you know they will change.
The problem isn't his politics. The problem is his last name.
How did you find the time to interview every Reublican and reach such a conclusion?  There are millions of us in this country.

Donaldo,

I don't have to interview anyone. The core beliefs of today's Republican Party: a white majority rooted in gerrymandered electoral mechanics, an irrational hatred of science and facts, adherence to Ayn Rand's idiotic pseudo philosophy, a dangerous lack of understanding of how this planet works and a consequent childish disregard for the environment, hatred of government and, with that, of civilization itself, among many other beliefs fueled by willful ignorance; all that makes Republicans unfit to govern. Keep in mind that if you personally differ from this pattern you're a Republican in Name Only and so, you should be OK.
There is simply no Republican fit to be president, Jeb Bush included. I would vote for a roll of toilet paper if it was the only alternative to voting for a Republican. Stop promoting this clown.
